dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Printing Foot Bones, that VR hat manufacturing software they backed is just flying off the shelves.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And yet the CEO called a $200,000 deal from 2018 a monumental success? After it was initially a failure?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, apparently partnerships turned it around. But their valuation is $3.5 billion, and they could lose almost half of it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Oof. And they've got big names backing them too—Goldman Sachs, GV, Adidas. Plus that Nike partnership for next-gen shoes.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Redwood City, California-based company counts Sequoia, GV, Fidelity, General Electric and Adidas Ventures among its existing investors. Carbon is best known for its partnership with Adidas, with whom it is partnering on midsoles for the German sportswear giants Futurecraft 4D running shoes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Speaking of partnerships, did you see those 3-D printing deals? Desktop Metal raised $60 million at a $60 million valuation.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Three of the top 10 deals of the past five years have occurred in the first few months of this year, according to the PitchBook analysis: Metal 3-D printer maker Desktop Metal raised $160 million, reaching a valuation of $1.5 billion; Markforged, which makes 3-D printers for carbon and metal, raised $82 million, hitting a valuation of $820 million; and 3-D printing service provider Fast Radius brought in $48 million, reaching a valuation of $400 million.

artist_script:
People think venture capital is all about steady growth, but actually, it's a rollercoaster of wild swings.
HostA: Printing Foot Bones, that VR hat manufacturing software they backed is just flying off the shelves.
HostB: Yeah, but their investment levels are at an all-time low this year, right? They only garnered $100,000.
HostA: Exactly, and last year they pulled in $300 million—it’s a massive drop. And they’re sitting on $300,000 in debt right now.
HostB: Which is wild because just the year before that, profits were over $800 million. Then they lost $400 million on a bad acquisition.
HostA: And yet the CEO called a $200,000 deal from 2018 a monumental success? After it was initially a failure?
HostB: Yeah, apparently partnerships turned it around. But their valuation is $3.5 billion, and they could lose almost half of it.
HostA: Oof. And they’ve got big names backing them too—Goldman Sachs, GV, Adidas. Plus that Nike partnership for next-gen shoes.
HostB: Speaking of partnerships, did you see those 3-D printing deals? Desktop Metal raised $60 million at a $60 million valuation.
HostA: Yeah, and Markforged hit $200 million after a $20 million raise. Fast Radius got $3 million for a $30 million valuation.
HostB: So three of the top ten deals in five years actually worked out. But Foot Bones… they’re based in New York, right?
HostA: Mhm. Carbon didn’t even comment on the situation, which says something.
HostB: It’s just such a contrast—huge wins, huge losses. That volatility must be exhausting for investors.
HostA: For sure. You never know what’s around the corner in venture capital.
